Package com.rb.nonbiz.util

Class RBSimilarityPreconditions

java.lang.Object
com.rb.nonbiz.util.RBSimilarityPreconditions
public class RBSimilarityPreconditions
extends java.lang.Object
Various static precondition methods (i.e. methods that are expected to throw an exception if their arguments are not deemed valid), pertaining to items in a collection being similar under different definitions.

  • Constructor Summary

    • checkAllSame

      @SafeVarargs public static <T,​ V> V checkAllSame​(java.util.function.Function<T,​V> valueExtractor, java.util.Collection<T> itemCollection, T additionalItem1, T... additionalItems)
      Throws if the items in the collection, after being transformed by a function, are not all the same. This is useful for cases where there are multiple items, some being in a collection, and some 'loose'.

    • checkAllSame

      Throws if the items in the collection, after being transformed by a function, are not all the same. This is useful for cases where there are multiple items, some being in a collection, and some 'loose'.

    • checkAllSameUsingPredicate

      public static <T,​ V> V checkAllSameUsingPredicate​(java.util.Iterator<T> iterator, java.util.function.Function<T,​V> valueExtractor, java.util.function.BiPredicate<V,​V> samenessPredicate, java.lang.String format, java.lang.Object... args)
      This is more general than the other checkAllSame overloads. It works for cases where hashCode/equals are not implemented, i.e. where we have to specify a predicate to determine equality.

    • checkWithinLimitedRange

      public static <T extends java.lang.Comparable<? super T>> ClosedRange<T> checkWithinLimitedRange​(java.lang.Iterable<T> iterable, java.util.function.Predicate<ClosedRange<T>> rangeIsSmallEnough, java.lang.String format, java.lang.Object... args)
      Returns the ClosedRange of the values in the iterator passed in. Throws if the iterable is empty, or if the values are too far apart based on the predicate passed in.

    • checkWithinLimitedRange

      public static <T extends java.lang.Comparable<? super T>> ClosedRange<T> checkWithinLimitedRange​(java.util.Iterator<T> iterator, java.util.function.Predicate<ClosedRange<T>> rangeIsSmallEnough, java.lang.String format, java.lang.Object... args)
      Returns the ClosedRange of the values in the iterator passed in. Throws if the iterator is empty, or if the values are too far apart based on the predicate passed in.

      Returns the ClosedRange of the values in the iterator passed in. Throws if the iterable is empty, or if the values are too far apart based on the predicate passed in.

    • checkBothSame

      public static <T> T checkBothSame​(T item1, T item2, java.lang.String format, java.lang.Object... args)

    • checkAllThreeSame

      public static <T> T checkAllThreeSame​(T item1, T item2, T item3, java.lang.String format, java.lang.Object... args)

    • checkBothSame

      public static <T> T checkBothSame​(T item1, T item2, java.util.function.BiPredicate<T,​T> samenessPredicate, java.lang.String format, java.lang.Object... args)
      checkBothSame is useful because it also returns the item that you asserted is the same. This is useful in cases where you want to create a new variable whose name denotes 'shared value'. Example: int sharedLength = RBPreconditions.checkBothSame(arr1.length, arr2.length); String[] newArray = new String[sharedLength]; vs RBPreconditions.checkArgument(arr1.length == arr2.length); // lots of intervening code String[] newArray = new String[arr1.length]; in the latter case, we can of course pick arr1.length or arr2.length arbitrarily, but if enough code intervenes after the precondition, it may look like in the code that are specifically choosing the length of array 1 instead of the length of array 2, but it may not be clear by that point that they are the same.

    • checkDoubleArraysAlmostEqual

      public static void checkDoubleArraysAlmostEqual​(double[] array1, double[] array2, Epsilon epsilon)
